Award.AwardTitle: SPARK - Increasing the Recruitment and Retention of Female Undergraduates in Engineering and Computer Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project will create a scholarship program called SPARK to offer eighteen scholarships to an undergraduate cohort comprised of first year, low income, academically talented engineering, and computer science majors at Texas State University - San Marcos. Scholarship support will continue for 3 years. Targeted recruiting and clearly defined selection criteria will help to create a strong cohort. Participants will live in a shared community integrating learning, mentoring, and academic enrichment. They will also participate in two highly engaged experiential learning summer sessions created specifically for the scholarship program. SPARK will help students refine skills critical to success in a 21st century workforce: adaptability, problem solving, innovation, empowerment, and leadership through the shared residential learning community, co-enrollment in STEM-related courses, a dedicated first year university transition course, and special summer sessions. Regular mentoring sessions will focus on career exploration, personal development, and research opportunities. The project will increase the number of talented female students attaining undergraduate engineering and computer science (ECS) degrees and contribute to the effort to achieve a more diverse STEM workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The national workforce needs well educated, technically savvy workers. There were over 8.3 million STEM jobs as of May 2014 - and they're growing more rapidly than non-STEM jobs. With women significantly underrepresented in engineering and computer science, making these career fields more accessible and attractive to women can increase the pool of skilled, well trained workers. Only 13% of the engineers in the U.S. are women; 26% are computing professionals. Recent findings cite that nearly 40 percent of women who earn engineering degrees leave the profession or never enter the field. Moreover, the percentage of women in computing is virtually the same as in 1960. Strategic changes are necessary to modify these statistics, and universities are in a key position to just do that.

Significant demographic enrollment growth at Texas State University has fueled an increase in the numbers of undergraduate students majoring in engineering and computer science. However, the number of our female students earning engineering and and computer science degrees has not increased correlatively. At present nationwide, 18 to 20 percent of engineering students are women. Our percentages were much lower - 13 to 14 percent - and we recognized the imperative to do better. With funding from the NSF S-STEM program, we developed SPARK - a program to evaluate if and how positive, early career path experiences and support structures could improve female students' interest, engagement and retention in these career fields.

Intellectual Merit: The program activities and research generated from this project has become part of the larger literature on sustaining female students' interest in engineering and computer science. To assess the program's effectiveness, we tracked 28 first year students through graduation.We performed statistical analyses of the data collected every semester on surveys regarding students' spatial visualization skills, self-confidence, efficacy, grit, GPA's and impact of program elements in students' performance. Notably, of all self-report variables assessed over the course of the program, spatial visualization skills average scores either at intake or after the training offered were higher for those students who remained eligible in the program (74.9%) relative to those who did not retain eligibility (60.0%), consistent with literature suggesting that spatial visualization skills are critical for the academic success in STEM majors.

Women particularly benefit from a culture of inclusiveness, sense of belonging, peer network and professional role modeling as the one created by SPARK. Significant scholarship support has opened doors to a college education for these talented, low income female students who otherwise might not have been able to afford a college degree. Community-building through shared one-year residential living contributed to female students' sense of purpose, self-confidence and grit. Faculty mentoring and coaching was transformative for female students who had experienced discouragement or disapproval prior to coming to the university. Regular interactions with program leaders and industry professionals sustained motivation and created curiosity about the many career possibilities in these degree fields. Project findings were presented at conferences (2014 New Horizons in STEM Education Conference, 2016 American Society of Engineering Education Annual Conference & Exposition, 36th Annual Conference on The First-Year Experience), and program information and accomplishments were disseminated regularly through social media (website, Facebook), local news (Austin American Statesman, San Marcos Daily Record, Texas State University's Hillviews), and through public talks and presentations.

Broader Impacts: SPARK participants are public advocates who interact in multidisciplinary settings to disseminate our core mission to encourage females to pursue careers in engineering and computer science. The program and its many supporters benefit society by expanding the national chorus of voices who advocate for gender equity in STEM fields. We strengthened our community ties through our industry partnerships (Tokyo Electron America, USAA) and outreach activities (e.g., GirlStart Girls in STEM Conference, PowerSet at Palacios High School, Harmony High Schoolers Bobcat for a Day). The project provided participants with the tools to become leaders in the national technical workforce and inspire future generations of girls and young women. Their contributions, as professionals and citizens, will broadly disseminate the vital participation of women in these fields and ignite new partnerships that advance women's full participation in STEM.
